Award.AwardTitle: Mechanistic Studies on the Reactions of Cobalamins with the Nitrogen Oxide Species NONOates and Peroxynitrite
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Research award in the Inorganic, Bioinorganic and Organometallic Chemistry program supports work by Professor Nicola Brasch at Kent State University to carry out studies on the reactions of vitamin B12 derivatives (cobalamins, Cbls) with NONOates and peroxynitrite. The rates and mechanisms of the reactions between Cbls and NONOates and the related N-substituted hydroxyamines will be determined. Determining the mechanisms of these reactions is important, given the widespread involvement of NONOates in biological systems and the broader impact extending to (H)NO-releasing pharmaceuticals. The overwhelming focus of non-clinical B12 research in the past four decades concerns its role in B12-dependent enzyme reactions, but there is increasing evidence that Cbls may reduce overproduction of reactive oxygen or nitrogen species such as nitric oxide and peroxynitrite. Cbls efficiently scavenge nitric oxide; however it is not yet known whether they react with the much more potent peroxynitrite. Rates and mechanisms of the reactions between Cbls and peroxynitrite will be determined. The ability of Cbls to inhibit peroxynitrite-induced tyrosine nitration is also being explored.

An Immersive Classroom featuring a Virtual Reality Environment Wall for 3-D stereoscopic visualization was recently installed in the Department of Chemistry at Kent State University. Teaching modules on B12 coenzymes and vitamin B12 suitable for a senior Inorganic Chemistry class and a graduate class in Bioinorganic Chemistry are in development and will be made available to others via the web. This research will improve our understanding of the chemistry of NONOates, peroxynitrite and vitamin B12, and, in the longer term, will provide fundamental scientific information potentially useful as a broader impact in the development of better therapeutics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mechanistic Studies on the Reactions of Cobalamins with the Nitrogen Oxide Species NONOates and Peroxynitrite.

The overwhelming focus of non-clinical B12 research in the past four decades is its role in the B12-dependent enzyme reactions. However cobalamins (Cbls, vitamin B12 derivatives) exhibit effects that cannot be attributed to their role in these reactions. For example, B12-dependent enzyme reactions are inhibited by nitric oxide (NO), and Cbls attenuate several nitric oxide - induced physiologies and pathologies. Despite the apparent diversity of chronic inflammatory diseases, they share a common factor – oxidative/nitrosative stress. Oxidative/nitrosative stress is associated with elevated levels of reactive species such as nitric oxide, superoxide, hydrogen peroxide, the hydroxyl radical and peroxynitrite, which react causing irreversible damage to proteins, lipids and DNA. It is likely that Cbl scavenges nitric oxide in biological systems to form nitrosylcobalamin (NOCbl). This has led to renewed interest in Cbl's potential for treating chronic inflammatory diseases. High levels of peroxynitrite, a potent oxidant and a nitrating and hydroxylating agent, are also implicated in chronic inflammatory disorders but it is not yet known if Cbls also react with, and potentially even scavenge, peroxynitrite.

This research focused on elucidating rates and mechanisms for novel, previously unknown reactions. This allows an evaluation of the biological importance and synthetic potential of these reactions. The first goal of this proposal was to determine rates and mechanisms of the reactions between Cbls and NONOates (diazeniumdiolates) and the related N-substituted hydroxyamines. Our studies on the reactions of cobalamins with R2N-NONOates show, for the first time, that these species can react directly with transition metal complexes.  This is important since a significant proportion of proteins have transition metal complexes at their active sites. R2N-NONOates are widely used in biological studies as nitric oxide precursors and are also currently being explored for their therapeutic potential.  It is generally assumed that R2N-NONOates themselves are not reactive, and that decomposition of R2N-NONOates to release NO is a prerequisite for their reactivity.  Our studies show that this is not necessarily the case.  

HNO donor compounds spontaneously decompose to form HNO (nitroxyl). It has recently been suggested that HNO, is formed in biological systems. HNO donor compounds also show considerable promise in treating congestive heart failure. Our mechanistic studies on the reactions of cobalamins with the most common HNO donor compound used in biological studies, Angeli’s salt, yielded interesting results and once again a novel reaction mechanism was elucidated. Our results provide fundamental information on the reactivity of HNO with transition metal complexes and this chemistry may potentially occur for proteins incorporating a transition metal complex.

In Specific Aim 2 the mechanisms of the reactions of peroxynitrite with cobalamins were explored.  Peroxynitrite formation is associated with many debilitating diseases and developing therapeutics which efficiently scavenge peroxynitrite is therefore an active area of research.  Vitamin B12 deficiency is associated with serious and life-threatening health conditions. The vitamin B12 derivatives cob(II)alamin and cob(I)alamin are important forms of vitamin B12 found in all mammalian cells. Our studies show that cob(I)alamin and cob(II)alamin react rapidly with peroxynitrite. This reactivity is consistent with experiments showing that both mammalian B12-dependent enzyme reactions are inactive under ...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Mechanistic Studies on the Reactions of Cobalamins with the Nitrogen Oxide Species NONOates and Peroxynitrite. The overwhelming focus of non-clinical B12 research in the past four decades is its role in the B12-dependent enzyme reactions. However cobalamins (Cbls, vitamin B12 derivatives) exhibit effects that cannot be attributed to their role in these reactions. For example, B12-dependent enzyme reactions are inhibited by nitric oxide (NO), and Cbls attenuate several nitric oxide - induced physiologies and pathologies. Despite the apparent diversity of chronic inflammatory diseases, they share a common factor – oxidative/nitrosative stress. Oxidative/nitrosative stress is associated with elevated levels of reactive species such as nitric oxide, superoxide, hydrogen peroxide, the hydroxyl radical and peroxynitrite, which react causing irreversible damage to proteins, lipids and DNA. It is likely that Cbl scavenges nitric oxide in biological systems to form nitrosylcobalamin (NOCbl). This has led to renewed interest in Cbl's potential for treating chronic inflammatory diseases. High levels of peroxynitrite, a potent oxidant and a nitrating and hydroxylating agent, are also implicated in chronic inflammatory disorders but it is not yet known if Cbls also react with, and potentially even scavenge, peroxynitrite. This research focused on elucidating rates and mechanisms for novel, previously unknown reactions. This allows an evaluation of the biological importance and synthetic potential of these reactions. The first goal of this proposal was to determine rates and mechanisms of the reactions between Cbls and NONOates (diazeniumdiolates) and the related N-substituted hydroxyamines. Our studies on the reactions of cobalamins with R2N-NONOates show, for the first time, that these species can react directly with transition metal complexes. This is important since a significant proportion of proteins have transition metal complexes at their active sites. R2N-NONOates are widely used in biological studies as nitric oxide precursors and are also currently being explored for their therapeutic potential. It is generally assumed that R2N-NONOates themselves are not reactive, and that decomposition of R2N-NONOates to release NO is a prerequisite for their reactivity. Our studies show that this is not necessarily the case. HNO donor compounds spontaneously decompose to form HNO (nitroxyl). It has recently been suggested that HNO, is formed in biological systems. HNO donor compounds also show considerable promise in treating congestive heart failure. Our mechanistic studies on the reactions of cobalamins with the most common HNO donor compound used in biological studies, AngeliÆs salt, yielded interesting results and once again a novel reaction mechanism was elucidated. Our results provide fundamental information on the reactivity of HNO with transition metal complexes and this chemistry may potentially occur for proteins incorporating a transition metal complex. In Specific Aim 2 the mechanisms of the reactions of peroxynitrite with cobalamins were explored. Peroxynitrite formation is associated with many debilitating diseases and developing therapeutics which efficiently scavenge peroxynitrite is therefore an active area of research. Vitamin B12 deficiency is associated with serious and life-threatening health conditions. The vitamin B12 derivatives cob(II)alamin and cob(I)alamin are important forms of vitamin B12 found in all mammalian cells. Our studies show that cob(I)alamin and cob(II)alamin react rapidly with peroxynitrite. This reactivity is consistent with experiments showing that both mammalian B12-dependent enzyme reactions are inactive under oxidative/nitrosative stress conditions. Nitration of tyrosine residues of proteins is widely used to indicate peroxynitrite formation in biological systems. Cob(II)alamin was found to prevent peroxynitrite-induced nitration of tyrosine.
